course.subject: MATH
course.name: Game Theory
course.description: Zero-sum games; minimax theorem; games in extensive form; strategic equilibrium; bi-matrix games; repeated Prisonner's Dilemma; evolutionary stable strategies; games in coalition form; core; Shapley Value; Power Index; two-side matching games.
course.prerequisites: (MATH 2011 OR MATH 2023 OR MATH 3043) AND (MATH 2111 OR MATH 2121 OR MATH 2131 OR MATH 2350)

reviews.author: clhappy
reviews.title: Do revision on your own is better
reviews.comment_content:
Total 4 topics. Topic 1 and Topic 2 are test in mid-term; topic 3 and topic 4 (may include one more small topic) are test in final.

mid term: zero sum game, non zero sum game, mix-strategies, values of game matrix (all have discrete no. of strategies) It has "proof" quesitons.

final: all are continuous strategies, have around 8-9topics. But in the exam he will tell us which topics are examined.

And, to do revision, just revise the proof, and study the specific topics that he stated, which will be examined.

reviews.author: Daisuke
reviews.comment_content:
Course對數學既要求唔高，需要基本既Linear Algebra(識得搵matrix inverse，transpose等等)，同埋基本既calculus，(例如用dy/dx=0去搵y(x)既max/min)。除左係prove von Neumann Theorem 用過條Brouwer fixed point theorem 之外，都唔會再有基本calculus同linear algebra以外既野，雖然係掛住MATH course既名，但即使唔係MATH major都可以應付到course既內容。

Course內容分為4個Topics，頭兩個Topics包括一啲基本terms同definition，同埋介紹幾種常見既game。

而後面兩個topics主要講(Noisy/Silent) Deal，Auction，Voting，同埋合作。

For reference:
Topic One: Zero-sum games and saddle point equilibriums
1.1 Definitions and examples
– Essential elements of a game
– Game matrix and game tree representation of a game
– Expected payoff and rational decision making
– Examples: Nim, Evens or Odds game, Russian Roulette
1.2 Saddle points
– Value of a zero sum game under pure strategies
– Characterization of saddle points
1.3 Mixed strategies for zero sum games
– Expected payoff under mixed strategies
– von Neumann minimax theorem
– Computational procedure and graphical solution
– Invertible matrix games: optimal target choice
– Symmetric games: Rock-paper-scissors

Topic Two: Nonzero sum games and Nash equilibrium
2.1 Dominant-strategy equilibrium and Nash equilibrium models
– Dominant and dominated strategies
– Iterated dominance: Battle of the Bismark Sea
– Characterization of Nash equilibrium
– Examples: Prisoner’s dilemma; Cuban crisis; battle of sexes;
coordination games
2.2 Mixed strategies
– Matching pennies and stochastic steady state profile
– Mixed strategy Nash equilibrium
– Best response functions
– Equality of payoff theorem (indifference principle)
– Safety values

Topic Three: Games with a continuum of strategies
3.1 Nash equilibrium point under a continuum of strategies
– Calculus approach of finding a Nash point
– Electoral competition
– Buy-it-now price of an item
– Tragedy of the commons
3.2 Economic applications
– Cournot model
– Stackelberg model

Topic Four – Coalitions and bargaining
4.1 Power indexes in coalitions
• Weighted voting games
• Shapley-Shubik index and Banzhaf index
• Probabilistic characterization of power indexes
4.2 Bargaining games
• Pareto-optimal boundary and status quo payoff point
• Nash model with security point
reviews.comment_teaching:
每個Topic 有~120頁既powerpoint， 即係Total大概500頁要睇。雖然數量多但係content只係基本calculus同linear algebra。但無奈排版上睇死人。因為個排版問題，搞到明明好容易既野變到好難follow(試唸下以Powerpoint既排版寫證明同定義會發生咩事，powerpoint個頁面打橫，而佢每條fomular都開新行，結果明明有好多空間但係就係好快用完一頁，啲Example有時又會係中間插張圖，搞到每個證明，每個example都要用好多頁寫，睇一個簡單prove都要揭好多次去搵佢啲terms)

而且佢份野無Index，有時個係個Topic中間插幾個好長既Examples，之後又翻去definition，完全估唔到佢會點接。要溫嗰陣完全唔知佢啲terms define左係邊，搞到只能夠用PDF既search功能去慢慢搵關鍵字出來。再加上佢既教學唔跟powerpoint流程，經常由Topic 1 跳左去Topic 2，然後講幾段又係下個Lecture跳翻去Topic 1，令學生對佢個流程混亂，就算有去上堂，都好難recall翻佢幾時教呢個section。

由於要一個sem教500頁powerpoint，所以一堂大概講20幾頁powerpoint，基本上就係將powerpoint既內容講翻出來，再加上佢雀躍般既教學流程同埋一個Example 就10幾頁既排版，就算去上堂都會覺得唔容易follow。而佢既powerpoint已經將course要教既內容寫得好詳細，所以唔去上堂都唔會有問題。

reviews.author: tesserakt
reviews.title: Applied MATH2023 and beyond
reviews.comment_content:
The course covers a basic introduction of game theory, starting from two-person zero-sum game and saddle point, then expanding them into two-person non-zero-sum game and Nash equilibrium. Some well-known examples like prisoner's dilemma and coordination game are included.

After the mid-term, the course then moves on to general N-person games with a continuum of strategies, including some of its most important applications like Stackelberg and Cournot model as well as auction games. Finally, voting systems and bargain game are also included.

Overall, the vast majority of the course is about optimization problems in real life using mathematical techniques, most notably multivariable calculus. You will find this course to be interesting if you like mathematical modelling.

Even though the course lists MATH2121 (or similar) as its prerequisites, the application of linear algebra here is minimal.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Prof. Kwok likes to emphasize the concepts behind the modelling instead of the mathematical details. However, he can dwell on the same topic for too long. Combined with his unfortunate tendency to go stray from the topic, his prose can be ponderous and hard to follow at times.

From how the lecture notes include detailed explanation and graphs behind the proofs, it can be seen that he has seriously designed them. However, they suffer from the same problem as the professor.
reviews.comment_grading:
40% mid-term (mean: 23.58, SD: 9.79)
60% final (mean: 28.77, SD: 15.38)

All of the exam problems come from lecture notes and examples. Some of them requires you to reproduce the proof discussed in class. As the final requires you to finish eight problems within 2 hours and 15 minutes, time can be an issue.

While I got an A+ with 92/100 (1.66SD above mean), given that the overall mean is just ~53 (and I heard that it is in C range), I cannot really say that the grading is good.
reviews.comment_workload:
As there are no homework that needs to be submitted (the so-called "homework" he had are more like self-exercises), the overall workload is not heavy.

While the contents should be easy to follow as long as you have a solid background of multivariable calculus, you need to memorize some of the proofs for the exams.
